Yes, in response to the issue of low royalties, some streaming platforms have increased their payments to artists proportionately to their plays or given artists more control over their royalties. For example, in 2020, Spotify launched a program called "Artist Fundraising Pick," which allows fans to donate directly to their favorite artists during the COVID-19 pandemic. Tidal also offers the highest royalty rate among music streaming services, paying roughly twice what Spotify pays per stream.

Additionally, some artists have started to diversify their income sources by offering merchandise, concerts, and collaborations with brands. For instance, some artists sell exclusive merchandise on their websites, and others host exclusive concerts and performances. These activities help promote their brand and reach a wider audience while earning additional income.

Some musicians have also formed collective organizations such as the American Association of Independent Music (A2IM) and Independent Music Companies Association (IMPALA), among others, to represent them and negotiate fairer royalties with digital distributors and streaming services.

Overall, while the music industry still has room for improvement in terms of fair royalties and compensation for artists, technological advancements and the advent of new, innovative platforms for music distribution provide opportunities for artists to promote their music and gain greater recognition.
